accesskeys: Duplicate access keys cause keyboard shortcuts to malfunction, leaving users unable to navigate the page effectively.
area-alt: Image map areas require descriptions so screen reader users know where these interactive 'hotspots' lead.
aria-hidden-focus: Hiding an element from screen readers while keeping it focusable creates a 'ghost' element that confuses keyboard users.
button-name: Buttons without text (like icon-only buttons) give screen reader users no indication of what clicking them will do.
bypass: Skip links allow keyboard users to jump past repetitive navigation and get straight to the main content, saving time and effort.
color-contrast: Text with low contrast is difficult for users with low vision or those in bright environments to read.
duplicate-id-active: Duplicate IDs on buttons or links can cause assistive technology to skip elements or trigger the wrong action entirely.
empty-heading: Empty headings clutter the page structure for screen reader users, making it harder to find the actual content they need.
focus-visible: A visible focus indicator is the 'mouse cursor' for keyboard users; without it, they cannot see which element they are currently on.
frame-title: Frames require names so users navigating via assistive technology can identify the purpose of the embedded content.
heading-order: A logical heading hierarchy (H1, then H2, etc.) acts as a table of contents, helping users build a mental map of the page.
html-has-lang: Setting a language allows screen readers to use the correct accent and pronunciation, preventing the content from sounding like gibberish.
image-alt: Screen reader users rely on text descriptions to understand the meaning, context, and purpose of images.
image-redundant-alt: Repeating the same text in an image description and an adjacent caption creates a repetitive and annoying experience for screen reader users.
input-image-alt: Image-based buttons require alternative text so users know the function of the button (e.g., 'Search' or 'Submit').
label: Form fields without labels are inaccessible to screen reader users and make it impossible for them to know what data to enter.
landmark-no-duplicate-main: A page should only have one primary content area. Multiple 'main' landmarks confuse screen reader users who use them to jump straight to the unique content of a page.
landmark-one-main: Without a 'main' landmark, users navigating via assistive technology have no quick way to bypass navigation menus and get straight to the primary content.
landmark-banner-is-top-level: The banner (header) should be a direct child of the document. Nesting it inside other areas makes it harder for users to locate the site's global branding and search.
landmark-contentinfo-is-top-level: The contentinfo (footer) landmark provides essential metadata and contact info; nesting it inside other sections can hide it from structural navigation tools.
link-name: Links need clear, unique text so users know exactly where a link goes before they decide to click it.
list: Proper list markup tells screen readers how many items are in a group, helping users understand the scale of the information provided.
region: Landmarks (like 'nav' or 'main') allow users to skip directly to specific sections of the page without having to tab through everything else.
scrollable-region-focusable: If a scrolling box isn't focusable, keyboard users can't scroll through the content, effectively 'locking' it away from them.
select-name: Dropdown menus without names prevent screen reader users from knowing what selection they are being asked to make.
tabindex: Using a tabindex greater than 0 disrupts the natural navigation flow, making the page unpredictable and frustrating for keyboard users.
valid-lang: Using an invalid language code prevents screen readers from loading the correct voice profile for that specific language.
